posts.name:
Chase Dimond
Chase Dimond
posts.content:
Many bosses may hate me for this, but I'll say it anyway:

Most leaders ignore how profoundly they impact their employees' lives.

Сould not agree more withthat:

Having a kind leader is a blessing.
Having a toxic leader is a lesson.

Both shape you, but only one helps you thrive.

Here are 10 signs that you're lucky to have a kind leader:

1/ They encourage a healthy work-life balance.
2/ They listen actively to your ideas and concerns.
3/ They support your career goals and aspirations.
4/ They advocate for your professional development.
5/ They offer mentorship and guidance when needed.
6/ They trust you to make decisions and take initiative.
7/ They foster a positive and inclusive work environment.
8/ They provide constructive feedback to help you improve.
9/ They lead by example, demonstrating integrity and ethics.
10/ They celebrate your successes and recognize your contributions.

Remember:

If you have a toxic manager,
learn what not to do, so you never have to face it again.

But if you're lucky to have a kind leader,
seize the opportunity to grow under their guidance.

️ If this resonates with you, share this post.

Credit:(go follow her)

comments.commentText: If you're lucky to have a kind leader, seize the opportunity to grow under their guidance

Little appreciation from a kind leader boost courage 100%

While

Toxic one will always drain your energy...

Because he will never appreciate anything you do.
Kingsley Chinedu True. The greatest leader is not necessarily the one who does the greatest things. He is the one that gets the people to do the greatest things.
Chase Dimond Yes, and people will do much more when a leader appreciate them no matter how little they accomplished.

posts.content:
My Dear working Moms here’s my version of 𝐓𝐡𝐞 𝐔𝐧𝐰𝐫𝐢𝐭𝐭𝐞𝐧 𝐌𝐚𝐧𝐮𝐚𝐥 𝐨𝐟 𝐌𝐨𝐭𝐡𝐞𝐫𝐡𝐨𝐨𝐝

As working mothers, we often face unique challenges without a clear guidebook. No matter how hard we try, we may feel like we're not doing enough.

I recently shared my personal experiences navigating the complexities of motherhood in a video at
. From managing guilt to finding balance, I hope my story can offer support and solidarity to fellow working mothers.

Watch the video on YouTube and let's continue the conversation!

comments.commentText: Himanshi, your insights on the challenges of working motherhood resonate deeply. It's empowering to hear how you transformed your experiences into a source of strength and solidarity for others. Thank you for opening up this vital conversation.

posts.name:
Daniel Lordson
Daniel Lordson
posts.content:
Ever wondered how to get more people to your sales calls? 

You send emails, right? But sometimes they miss them or forget! Let’s change that. Imagine combining email with a smart voice AI. Sounds cool, right?

Here’s the issue: We all know that no-shows can zap your time and mood.  Your team tries so hard to book those calls, but folks either miss or skip them. Ouch.

Enter voice AI, the superhero of reminders! ‍️ Picture this: 60-90 minutes before the call, the AI gives your clients a quick call. It’s like a friendly nudge saying, “Hey, don’t forget about your call!”  And if they can’t make it? No worries! The AI helps them reschedule right away. Win-win!

This trick can boost your show rates and make your sales team happier.  Because more calls mean more chances to close the deal!

Want to see it in action? DM us and let’s set it up for you!

posts.name:
Jonathan Kennedy
Jonathan Kennedy
posts.content:
If you’re a professional in the Shopify ecosystem, and looking to start something… the list of problems merchants have is looonnngggg and still growing. 

I’ve spoken to 10 Shopify Plus merchants this week as part of a research project via- dogfooding as they say.

Below are a few topics that came up that seemed to be big pain points, and not even related to what we were researching - these problems came up adjacenctly.

Sidenote - talking to founders and operators about their businesses, challenges, successes and origin stories might be my favourite thing to do.

Pains:

- Optimizing and accounting for cross border sales and forex for Canadian, UK, EUR and AUS merchants. < anyone help or solve for this?

- B2B invoicing controls, formatting, post purchase editing and lack of connections with other key apps. < any vendor do this well?

- Summarizing of financial reports for optimal decision making. < fractional CFO but that can be expensive

- Buy back and resale systems for used, second hand and high value items. < low awareness of existing solutions

- Lack of continuity with account managers across agency and app vendors, and even Shopify itself. < best solution is hire internally

- How growth affects every part of the business and the founder/operator struggles to set priorities. < hire a coach

- Better, more specific categorization of book entries/line items. < Finaloop or Quickbooks app?

- Accurate real time inventory tracking when it’s not in the business’ own warehouse. Lack of trust in 3PL accuracy.

- Shopify POS limitations and lack of integrations with popular online store apps.

- Shopify SEO for founders, everything about it. < follow.

If you’re stuck with something, want to validate an idea you have OR want to find an idea, get on the phone with the right people, ask good questions and listen.

comments.commentText: Do you see any merchants looking for AI agents to move toward conversational commerce? Curious to see if the market is asking for it now or if it's more marketing hype.

Good question. 

I’ve seeing many solutions pop up recently - we have several teams running research studies right now on our platform - so I’d say the market is probably asking for it.

Shopify checkout (the transaction) and the online store (the order) are processed separately. This means you cannot tie a payout to a transaction to an order to an inventory deduction. If Shopify could find a way to align their reporting to make it easier to work with ERPs our runway with Shopify would be MUCH longer. It just takes too much labor to decode our reports each month. Custom reporting for base tiers was just rolled out but it still lacks any connection between the funds deposited (which much be reconciled) back to the order line items.

As a huge fan of the platform and the success it has brought us, it's tough to struggle so much with what our clients expect to be the "easy" part of the solution (reporting basic transaction data). Being "pretty" and "easy to setup" can only take you so far. Other platforms seem more able to report to ERPs at the sacrifice of UX and ease-of-use.

Our clients will show us the squarespace reports that we should be able to replicate - we just can't. It's an embarrassing moment in the discovery process.

I'll concede that I do understand by separating the checkout from store order each can be optimized independently, which has immense benefits - but only for startups.

posts.name:
Mike Karthauser
Mike Karthauser
posts.content:
Recruiters:

I've see you like to write "upto XXX salary" on your job specs.

Thats better than not having any salary (see previous rants from me) but can you do us all a favour by adding a "from XXX salary" and more importantly, how to get from the "from" to the "to".

I often see, "depending on experience" but that doesn't offer much help. If you are going to offer a "mid to senior" range why not get your client to decide what level they want and be more specific. What about the pay reviews and career progression?

No-one wants to go to a new job and stay on the same salary.

If you don't supply that information, and the next guy does, then your candidates will go to them.

comments.commentText: Just put a salary range there's what the job is worth at a minimum and there's what the job is worth plus added value.

posts.name:
Dr. Trishi Sharma
Dr. Trishi Sharma
posts.content:
Having 20K followers means nothing 
if they're the wrong 20K.

Every day I see accounts with massive
followings struggling to sign clients.

The pattern?

They chase growth over relevance.
Post viral content over valuable insights.
Build an audience that likes but never buys.

Here's the truth:

Many times
"Viral content ≠ Valuable content"

Your ideal clients need solutions,
not inspiration.

Your content should:

Solve specific problems
Showcase your expertise
Attract decision makers
Drive real conversations

Because followers don't pay invoices.
Clients do!

1000 likes from the wrong audience
won't grow your business.

But 100 views from the right people will.

Posting inspiring content occasionally?
Sure!

Making it your entire strategy?
That's leaving money on the table.

Focus on value.
The right audience will follow.

comments.commentText: Dr. Trishi, your insights resonate deeply with the challenges many face in balancing follower count and genuine engagement. It’s a crucial reminder that value-driven content outweighs mere numbers, and focusing on delivering solutions is key to nurturing meaningful relationships with potential clients. Thank you for emphasizing the importance of aligning our audiences with our business goals.
